awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Resurrecting natural history collections to assess evolutionary responses to climate change
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections.  The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways.  Understanding how organisms cope with environmental change is a fundamental goal in biology, and one that is increasingly pressing in the arid Southwestern U.S., where severe drought over the past several decades has challenged organisms in unprecedented ways.  There are generally two ways that organisms can acclimate to a changing climate: Non-genetic changes and genetic changes. Genetic changes are passed down across generations, allowing offspring to be more successful in the future.  This research will use preserved seed collections, together with natural populations that have descended from these same ancestors, to create an 'evolutionary time machine'.  By resurrecting seeds of dormant plant ancestors, and growing them together with their offspring under common conditions, this research will expose evolution in action.  Determining whether adaptation can keep pace with a rapidly changing climate has major implications for predicting the future of biodiversity, and the fate of individual populations and species.  This work will advance a basic understanding of adaptation, and will also inform management decisions, promoting ecosystem health and preserving biodiversity.

In investigating adaptation we are often limited to the endpoints of past processes, however resurrection experiments allow us to leverage preserved propagules to quantify evolutionary change across time.  The fellow will resurrect dormant seeds of Plantago patagonica, a widespread annual plant, from herbarium collections, and will compare them to contemporary genotypes collected from the same locations in a series of common gardens.  By replicating resurrections across an environmental gradient in northern Arizona, this work will simulate future drying and warming, and will assess how patterns of local adaptation might constrain adaptive potential.  This framework facilitates an understanding of the role of gene by environment interactions, and provides a framework for predicting future responses to climate change.  This work expands past resurrection implementations by growing ancestors and descendants in natural field environments, across a gradient of abiotic conditions, and by combining experimental data on phenotypic responses with genetic data documenting the demographic implications of selection.  In addition to its contributions to basic science, this work will promote a better understanding of evolutionary biology in the local community through collaborations with a non-profit STEM center.  The fellow will also lead undergraduates and members of the community in collecting seeds for a seed bank repository associated with the Southwest Experimental Garden Array; this effort will foster an appreciation for local plant biodiversity, and will amass seed resources from across a remarkable environmental gradient in northern Arizona to be used for future local adaptation and resurrection experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global climate change is posing unprecedented challenges to natural populations.  Variable precipitation events and a cumulative decrease in soil moisture over the past two decades have resulted in an ongoing millennial-scale megadrought in the southwestern United States.  One of the most outstanding questions in biology is whether natural populations can rapidly adapt to shifting climatic conditions associated with climate change, and if so, which traits might assist them in coping with novel environmental challenges?

Dr. Kyle Christie completed a Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology (PRFB), in which he explored the adaptive capacity of a native plant, Woolly Plantain (Plantago patagonica), and its evolutionary responses to intense drought in the southwestern U.S.  He used a "resurrection ecology" approach, reviving stored seeds which captured snapshots in time of natural populations prior to the onset of intense drought, and comparing them with seeds from contemporary populations that had experienced approximately 10-15 years of drought.  Dr. Christie applied a novel twist to the established resurrection approach, by using seeds stored on natural history collections (dried and pressed plant specimens), he was able to generate an "evolutionary time machine" without intentionally having collected natural seeds prior to the onset of environmental change.  This work demonstrated a new avenue for researchers hoping to use resurrection ecology to understand the ability of natural populations to adapt.

During his time as Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, Dr. Christie accomplished his major research objective of observing evolutionary responses to climate change in real time.  This work is scientifically noteworthy for several reasons.  First, Dr. Christie documented rapid trait evolution in Woolly Plantain, and further found that its evolution was adaptive, as contemporary populations had evolved greater drought tolerance compared to their ancestors.  Interesting, many similar studies have documented an acceleration of the life cycle in response to drought; however, this work showed that increased fitness under drought was likely related to tissue allocation strategies, in which greater investment in leaf and root tissue allowed contemporary populations to survive drought better than their ancestors.  Overall, this work adds to basic scientific knowledge related to the tempo of evolution in natural populations, and the varied life history strategies such populations can utilize to tolerate harsh abiotic conditions associated with climate-change induced drought.

Beyond the training of Dr. Christie as a research scientist, this project also had numerous broader impacts associated with mentorship and teaching across a broad cross-section of the community.  Dr. Christie directly mentored three graduate students during his PRFB tenure and taught an intensive one-week workshop on R programming for graduate students in the biological sciences.  At the undergraduate level, he mentored two students as part of independent research internships, including one through the immersive Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program.  He volunteered at a local STEM center serving under-represented K-12 students in the community and gave an outreach seminar educating the public about the intricacies and importance of biodiversity.

Dr. Christie's training as an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Biology has directly helped him to develop as a scientist, mentor, and teacher.  Work associated with this award has directly furthered our basic understanding of evolution and ecology in the face of global climate change, and has fostered the academic and public community through mentorship and teaching.
